person.note: On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2, pp. 17-8.
This is Herod (1) G/M, in vol. 1, p. 282.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
The event described here is associated with the death of John the Baptist. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2, pp. 17-8. On the interchange of the Latin suffixes us and ius see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.3, p. 19.
In Transjordan.

This inscription is clearly a pagan one, commemorating the dedication of an altar to Zeus. However, the name of the father may be understtod as distinctly Jewish (before the Christian era). However, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.4.1, p. 52.
The inscription is dated to the 10th year of the Emperor Hadrian, see Introduction 7.1.
On this form see vol. 3, under Annius (7) L/M, p. 457.
In Greek – μν θαυμων, see editorial comment.
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
On this form see vol. 1, under Antony (1) L/M, p. 327.
This is Herod (1) G/M, in vol. 1, p. 282.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
The event described here is associated with the death of John the Baptist. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1.
For the form ̓Ακυλας see vol. 3, under Aquila (1) L/M, p. 460. This is probably the vocative.
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
On this form see vol. 3, under Candidus (1) L/M, p. 477.

The inscription was found in a burial chamber in Jerusalem. If it dates from before 70 CE it was probably Jewish, see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, but there are coins in the cave from the 2nd century BCE to the 7th century CE.
If he is Jewish he dates to this period, but see previous note.
On this form see vol. 3, under Claudius (5) L/M, p. 480.
In Greek – τις λη́στς καὶ τὴν ̔Ιουδαίαν καὶ τὴν Συρίαν κατατρέχων (a certain brigand, overrunning Judaea and Syria …).
Was active in Judaea, but there is no evidence that he himself was a Jew, see Stern, GLAJJ 2, 407 for bibliography and opinions for and against his Jewishness.
This is the date, see Introduction 7.1 of the event Cassius Dio describes, see Introduction 7.1.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.

In vol. 1 I only recorded his son (Simon [160] B/M, p. 223) and considered him Jewish, based on name (Σιμωνίδης) but the premise is doubtful, and if his son was Jewish, so was he, see the discussion of the editors in CIIP.
The weight is dated according to the Emperor Claudius, see Introduction 7.1.
On this form see vol. 3, under Domitius (3) L/M, p. 486.
In this pseudepgraphic composition Described as one of Μαθηταὶ … ̓κτώ (eight disciples).
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
Was contemporary of Jesus.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.
In Lebanon.
Jewishness indicated by son’s name, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.8, pp. 52-3.
The inscription is dated, according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2, pp. 17-8.
This is Herod (1) G/M, in vol. 1, p. 282.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
The event described here is associated with the death of John the Baptist. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2, pp. 17-8.
In Greek – ̔Ασταιός. On this place in Palestine see Clermont-Ganneau, ibid, 357.
On the Tomb of the Prophet on the Mount of Olives and the character of the inscriptions read there see Introduction 8.1.2.1.
The editor of these inscriptions considered them Christian, but see previous note.
If the Tomb of the Prophets was a Jewish site, it had to have been in use before the destruction of the Temple, see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52, but see previous note.
On this form see vol. 1, under Gaius (5) L/M, p. 333.
Described as on of ἑτέρους μαθητὰς (other disciples). Perhaps identical with Gaius (1) L/M, in vol. 3, p. 493.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
Was contemporary of Jesus.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. On this form see vol. 1, under Gaius (5) L/M, p. 333.

person.note: Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see vol. 1, under Julius (3) L/M, p. 332.
This is Agrippa (2) L/M, in vol. 1, p. 325.
In Greek – [ἀ]γ[ο]ρ[α]νομ[ούντω]ν(who served as agoranomos – clerk of the market).
This was a clerk who served under the Jewish King Agrippa II, but he need not have been Jewish himself, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.9.2, p. 53.
The weight is dated to the 22 year of Agrippa, see Introduction 7.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see vol. 1, under Julius (3) L/M, p. 332.

person.note: In Greek – ΑΓΟΡΑ (agoranomos – clerk of the market).

See above, n. 5. This was a clerk who served under the Jewish King Agrippa II, but he need not have been Jewish himself, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.9.2, p. 53. Even more then for the previous this is true for this one, for he did not even serve under the supervision of a Jewish king but rather under direct Roman rule.
The weight is dated to the reign of the emperor Hadrian. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.
In Latin – Neapolitanus. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.

The persons mentioned in the inscription are described as “Flavius Neopolitanus,” indicating Nablus, the chief Samaritan city. However, they may have been colonists in the newly founded Roman Colony, since they mention their Roman tribal affiliation – Ter(etino). Samaritan identity may be suggested based on provenance, but see Introduction 6.1.5.
The transliteration is straightforward, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2, p. 17.
By Caesarea.

person.bibl: Solomon of Basra,Book of the Bee, 89
person.note: In Syriac, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.1, pp. 18-9. In Hebrew this would read יוסטוס. This is the most logical way to transliterate this name into Semitic characters, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.1, p. 17.
Appears in a list following the words ܫܡܗܐܵ ܝܢ ܕܪܥܵܘܬܐ ܐܝܬܝܗܘܢ ܗܠܝܢ (the names of the shepherds are these:).
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
The event took place at the birth of Jesus.
On this form see vol. 1, under Justus (1) L/M, p. 333.
In Greek – Τιβεριεύς.
In Greece.
Jewishness suggested by the frequency of the name Justus among Jews and by the provenance of this person – Palestine, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.8.1, p. 54.
On this form see vol. 1, under Lucius (1) L/M, p. 334.
This is Herod (1) G/M, in vol. 1, p. 282.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
The event described here is associated with the death of John the Baptist. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.1, p. 17. On the fall of the vowels see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4.
The inscription was found in the remains of the destroyed Samaritan Temple, see Introduction 8.1.1.1.
See previous note. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1 of the destruction of the Samaritan Temple.
On this form see vol. 1, under Marcus (1) L/M, p. 334.
He is Nabas (1) S-G/M, in vol. 1, p. 439.
Described in the text as οἱ ὄντες ἐκ περιτομῆς (who are of the circumcision).
Was contemporary of Jesus.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.

In vol. 1 I only recorded his son (Simon [160] B/M, p. 223) and considered him Jewish, based on name (Σιμωνίδης) but the premise is doubtful, and if his son was Jewish, so was he, see the discussion of the editors in CIIP.
The weight is dated according to the Emperor Claudius, see Introduction 7.1.
So in Deutsch, Tarbiz69 (2000) 184. For this form see vol. 1, Marinus (1) L/M, p. 335.

So in the parallel version in Krauss, Leben Jesu, p. 147. On the interchange of ס and ש in the transliteration of Greek and Latin names into Jewish characters see vol. 1, Introduction 2.2.5, pp. 20-1.
In Hebrew – הזקן.
See Introduction to Addendum.
The event takes place in the year Jesus was crucified, see Introduction 7.1.
Mentioned together with other direct, Palestinian disciples of Jesus.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
Was contemporary of Jesus.

In vol. 1 I only recorded his son (Simon [160] B/M, p. 223) and considered him Jewish, based on name (Σιμωνίδης) but the premise is doubtful, and if his son was Jewish, so was he, see the discussion of the editors in CIIP.
The weight is dated according to the Emperor Claudius, see Introduction 7.1.
The form is in dative. Either this is an attempt to transcribe in Latin a Greek dative or the I replaces an e.
In Latin – Suros.

Jewish identity was suggested by M. H. Wiliams, Jews among the Greeks and Romans: A Diaspora Sourcebook (London 1998) 197, n. 9, based on the name Matthias, which she claims is only known among Jews, but see vol. 3, under Mattathias B/M, p. 139, n. 1.
Dated to Galba’s emperorship. This is the only year in which he was emperor, see Introduction 7.1.
In Coptic, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read Ρουφος. On this form see vol. 1, under Rufus (1) L/M, p. 338.
In this text he is resurrected from the dead by a miracle performed by a Christian and this convinces him to convert.
Shortly after Jesus’ crucifixion.

state.note: Inscription on amphora, Jewish quarter, Jerusalem

person.note: Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see vol. 1, under Rufus (1) L/M, p. 338.
The amphora owner signed his name on it. The contents of amphora was consumed by Jews, but there is no indication that the producer was one, see also vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.1.3, p. 38.
The weight is dated to the 22 year of Agrippa, see Introduction 7.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 5. Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see vol. 1, under Rufus (1) L/M, p. 338.

person.note: In Greek – [ἀ]γ[ο]ρ[α]νομ[ούντω]ν(who served as agoranomos – clerk of the market).
This was clerk who served under the Jewish King Agrippa II, but he need not have been Jewish himself, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.9.2, p. 53.
The weight is dated to the 22 year of Agrippa, see Introduction 7.1.
On the form Σαβίνος see under Sabinus (4) L/M in this volume. For the initial α see Introduction 2.3.1.
The event takes place in ̓Αντιοχεία (Syria), in which he is a πολιτευομένου.
Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαῖου (Jew).
The event took place in the year of the emperor Commodus death, which is this one, see Introduction 7.1.
On this form see vol. 4, under Severus (1) L/M, p. 160.
By the Dead Sea.
The jar is dated to “year one” (שנת אחת) of either the First Revolt against Rome or the Bar Kokhba revolt, see Introduction 7.1.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.

In vol. 1 I only recorded his son (Simon [160] B/M, p. 223) and considered him Jewish, based on name (Σιμωνίδης) but the premise is doubtful, and if his son was Jewish, so was he, see the discussion of the editors in CIIP.
The weight is dated according to the Emperor Claudius, see Introduction 7.1.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2, pp. 17-8.
This is Herod (1) G/M, in vol. 1, p. 282.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
The event described here is associated with the death of John the Baptist. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1.

This ossuary was found together with another bearing the form Βεροῦτος, which was interpreted as the genitive of Verus, see vol. 1, under Verus (1) L/M, p 340. If that one was a Verus, so is this one, but see n. 1, there.
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
